title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@posit.co. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to aiddataviz
text: outlines propose change aiddataviz. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to aiddataviz
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to aiddataviz
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to aiddataviz
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("Teal-Insights/aiddataviz", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to aiddataviz
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to aiddataviz
text: Please note aiddataviz project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Teal Emery. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Emery T (2025). aiddataviz: Data Visualization Themes Tools AidData. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://teal-insights.github.io/aiddataviz/, https://github.com/Teal-Insights/aiddataviz.
code: @Manual{,   title = {aiddataviz: Data Visualization Themes and Tools for AidData},   author = {Teal Emery},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://teal-insights.github.io/aiddataviz/},   url = {https://github.com/Teal-Insights/aiddataviz}, }

title: Data Visualization Themes and Tools for AidData
text: aiddataviz ggplot2 extension package implements William & Mary’s brand guidelines AidData visualizations. provides themes, color palettes, helper functions create beautiful, accessible, -brand data visualizations. package created Teal Emery part applied data analysis course AidData staff. intended use AidData, official AidData product. NOTE: aiddataviz brand new still heavy development. feedback, can make awesome tool. Please understand work progress, likely breaking changes (code works today, may work tomorrow) coming weeks finalized.

title: Data Visualization Themes and Tools for AidData
text: can install development version aiddataviz GitHub :

title: Data Visualization Themes and Tools for AidData
text: load aiddataviz package library(aiddataviz), prompted install required fonts (Roboto Open Sans) automatically. Simply type y press enter install . ’d prefer install fonts manually, can get Google Fonts: - Roboto - Open Sans Windows, custom system fonts may unavailable default RMarkdown rendering engine. ’re trouble, try setting dev = "ragg_png" RMarkdown chunk options. example, add knitr::opts_chunk$set(dev = "ragg_png") top RMarkdown file.

title: Data Visualization Themes and Tools for AidData
text: ’s basic example showing use aiddataviz themes color scales create visualizations style AidData’s research publications:
code: library(aiddataviz) library(ggplot2) library(dplyr)  # Create a stacked bar chart of Chinese development finance flows ggplot(gcdf_yearly_flows,         aes(x = commitment_year,             y = commitments_bn,            fill = flow_class)) +   geom_col() +   labs(     title = "Chinese Official Finance Flows to Developing Countries",     subtitle = "Annual commitments by flow class, 2000-2021",     x = "Year",     y = "USD Billions (2021)",     fill = "Flow Class",     caption = "Source: AidData's Global Chinese Development Finance Dataset, Version 3.0"   ) +   scale_fill_aiddata(palette = "default") +   theme_aiddata()

title: Data Visualization Themes and Tools for AidData
text: package provides several color palettes based William & Mary’s brand guidelines, designed different visualization needs: Note: palettes developed based William & Mary’s brand guidelines analysis AidData’s publications. can adjusted based feedback AidData communications team.

title: Data Visualization Themes and Tools for AidData
text: default palette uses AidData’s three primary colors: Wren Twilight blue, Spirit Gold, Silver. palette ideal categorical data three groups matches style commonly used AidData’s publications.

title: Data Visualization Themes and Tools for AidData
text: single-variable visualizations, use Wren Twilight blue, William & Mary’s signature color.

title: Data Visualization Themes and Tools for AidData
text: Combines Wren Twilight blue Spirit Gold binary categorical data.

title: Data Visualization Themes and Tools for AidData
text: default palette, provided explicit naming consistency.

title: Data Visualization Themes and Tools for AidData
text: Adds Patina three-color palette visualizations requiring additional categories.

title: Data Visualization Themes and Tools for AidData
text: Incorporates Vine fifth color, completing primary color set.

title: Data Visualization Themes and Tools for AidData
text: gradient Griffin Green College Woods Patina light gray. Ideal ordered data darker values indicate higher intensity.

title: Data Visualization Themes and Tools for AidData
text: gradient Spirit Gold Colonial Yellow light gray. Provides alternative green sequence maintains AidData’s visual identity.

title: Data Visualization Themes and Tools for AidData
text: diverging palette centered silver, moving Griffin Green Patina one end Colonial Yellow Spirit Gold . Ideal data meaningful center points positive/negative values.

title: Data Visualization Themes and Tools for AidData
text: alternative diverging palette using Vine Weathered Brick College Sky. Useful want avoid green/gold associations need different visual emphasis.

title: Add two numbers — add_numbers
text: sum x y

title: AidData Colors and Palettes — aiddata_colors
text: comprehensive color system based William & Mary's brand guidelines. colors organized primary, secondary/tertiary, neutral groups. See https://brand.wm.edu/index.php/university-colors/ original brand guidelines.

title: AidData Colors and Palettes — aiddata_colors
text: object class list length 18. object class list length 10.

title: AidData Colors and Palettes — aiddata_colors
text: Colors organized groups: Primary Colors: Wren Twilight (wren_twilight): Deep navy blue (#00313C) Vine (vine): Rich burgundy (#84344E) Patina (patina): Vibrant teal (#00B388) Spirit Gold (spirit_gold): Bright gold (#F0B323) Silver (silver): Light gray (#D0DED4) Secondary & Tertiary Colors: Colonial Yellow (colonial_yellow): Muted gold (#CAB64B) College Sky (college_sky): Light blue (#64CCC9) Weathered Brick (weathered_brick): Coral red (#E56A54) Moss (moss): Olive green (#789D4A) College Woods (college_woods): Sage green (#789F90) Slate (slate): Medium gray (#5B6770) Griffin Green (griffin_green): Deep forest green (#183028) Neutral Grays: Gray 90-10: range grays light dark NA Color (na_color): Special gray missing values

title: AidData Colors and Palettes — aiddata_colors
text: Several pre-defined palettes available: Categorical Palettes: default: Three primary colors (Wren Twilight, Spirit Gold, Silver) one_color: Single color (Wren Twilight) two_colors: Two colors (Wren Twilight, Spirit Gold) three_colors: default four_colors: Adds Patina three_colors five_colors: Adds Vine four_colors Sequential Palettes: sequential_green: Griffin Green Gray90 sequential_gold: Spirit Gold Gray90 Diverging Palettes: diverging_green_gold: Griffin Green Spirit Gold diverging_vine_sky: Vine College Sky

title: AidData Colors and Palettes — aiddata_colors
code: # Access individual colors aiddata_colors$wren_twilight #> Wren Twilight  #>     "#00313C"  aiddata_colors$spirit_gold #> Spirit Gold  #>   "#F0B323"   # Use with ggplot2 library(ggplot2)  # Categorical data with default palette ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg, color = factor(cyl))) +   geom_point() +   scale_color_aiddata()   # Sequential data ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg, color = disp)) +   geom_point() +   scale_color_aiddata(palette = "sequential_green", discrete = FALSE)

text: family_name name font family. silent want suppress message? check_only logical. TRUE, checks fonts available without attempting register .

title: Make font families available in ggplot2 — font_hoist
text: function returns message indicating whether font successfully loaded .

title: Make font families available in ggplot2 — font_hoist
text: See June Choe's blog post explaining . function requires user already downloaded font computer, set ragg described blog post.

title: Make font families available in ggplot2 — font_hoist
code: # load Roboto (must be loaded from Google Fonts on system already) font_hoist("Roboto") #> No fonts found for the family 'Roboto'.  #> Make sure that the font is downloaded to your computer, and that you can find it using systemfonts::system_fonts(). #> $specs #> NULL #>  #> $available #> [1] FALSE #>   # Try loading a font not on your computer, or that doesn't exist. # It will give an informative error message. font_hoist("Lobster Monster") #> No fonts found for the family 'Lobster Monster'.  #> Make sure that the font is downloaded to your computer, and that you can find it using systemfonts::system_fonts(). #> $specs #> NULL #>  #> $available #> [1] FALSE #>

what: Chinese Development Finance Commitments by Country — gcdf_country_commitments
title: Chinese Development Finance Commitments by Country — gcdf_country_commitments
text: dataset containing Chinese development finance commitments related country characteristics derived Global Chinese Development Finance (GCDF) Dataset 3.0, World Bank World Development Indicators, IMF World Economic Outlook data. dataset includes total commitments, weighted average interest rates, key country characteristics like GDP, population, region income group.

title: Chinese Development Finance Commitments by Country — gcdf_country_commitments
Chinese Development Finance Commitments by Country — gcdf_country_commitments
text: data frame approximately 150 rows 8 variables: country_name Character. Country name iso3c Character. ISO 3-letter country code total_commitments_bn Numeric. Total Chinese development finance commitments billions constant 2021 USD weighted_interest_rate Numeric. Weighted average interest rate across loans, weighted commitment amount region_name Character. World Bank geographic region income_level_name Character. World Bank income group classification gdp_usd_bn Numeric. Nominal GDP billions USD (2021) population_mn Numeric. Population millions (2021)

title: Chinese Development Finance Commitments by Country — gcdf_country_commitments
text: GCDF 3.0 Commitment interest rate data AidData's Global Chinese Development Finance Dataset, Version 3.0 WDI Region income group classifications World Bank World Development Indicators WEO GDP population data IMF World Economic Outlook (Fall 2024)

title: Chinese Development Finance Commitments by Country — gcdf_country_commitments
code: # Get top 10 recipients by commitment amount gcdf_country_commitments |>   dplyr::arrange(desc(total_commitments_bn)) |>   head(10) #> # A tibble: 10 × 8 #>    country_name iso3c total_commitments_bn weighted_interest_rate region_name    #>    <chr>        <chr>                <dbl>                  <dbl> <chr>          #>  1 Russia       RUS                  170.                    3.86 Europe & Cent… #>  2 Argentina    ARG                  139.                    7.17 Latin America… #>  3 Venezuela    VEN                  113.                    5.02 Latin America… #>  4 Pakistan     PAK                  103.                    3.63 South Asia     #>  5 Angola       AGO                   65.1                   4.34 Sub-Saharan A… #>  6 Kazakhstan   KAZ                   64.1                   4.60 Europe & Cent… #>  7 Indonesia    IDN                   55.2                   4.87 East Asia & P… #>  8 Brazil       BRA                   54.3                   3.82 Latin America… #>  9 Vietnam      VNM                   28.9                   3.73 East Asia & P… #> 10 Turkey       TUR                   28.3                   3.82 Europe & Cent… #> # ℹ 3 more variables: income_level_name <chr>, gdp_usd_bn <dbl>, #> #   population_mn <dbl>  # Calculate average commitment size by region gcdf_country_commitments |>   dplyr::group_by(region_name) |>   dplyr::summarize(     avg_commitment_bn = mean(total_commitments_bn, na.rm = TRUE)   ) #> # A tibble: 7 × 2 #>   region_name                avg_commitment_bn #>   <chr>                                  <dbl> #> 1 East Asia & Pacific                   9.45   #> 2 Europe & Central Asia                16.7    #> 3 Latin America & Caribbean            12.5    #> 4 Middle East & North Africa            6.47   #> 5 South Asia                           22.8    #> 6 Sub-Saharan Africa                    6.38   #> 7 NA                                    0.0599  # Create basic visualization of commitments by income group if (requireNamespace("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE)) {   ggplot2::ggplot(     gcdf_country_commitments,     ggplot2::aes(x = income_level_name, y = total_commitments_bn)   ) +     ggplot2::geom_boxplot() }

what: Chinese Development Finance Commitments by Year and Flow Class — gcdf_yearly_flows
title: Chinese Development Finance Commitments by Year and Flow Class — gcdf_yearly_flows
text: time series dataset containing annual Chinese development finance commitments broken flow class (e.g., ODA-like, OOF-like, etc.) Global Chinese Development Finance Dataset 3.0. Values constant 2021 USD.

title: Chinese Development Finance Commitments by Year and Flow Class — gcdf_yearly_flows
Chinese Development Finance Commitments by Year and Flow Class — gcdf_yearly_flows
text: data frame approximately 100 rows 3 variables: commitment_year Integer. Year commitment flow_class Character. Classification financial flow (ODA-like, OOF-like, Vague Official Finance) commitments_bn Numeric. Total commitments billions constant 2021 USD

title: Chinese Development Finance Commitments by Year and Flow Class — gcdf_yearly_flows
text: AidData's Global Chinese Development Finance Dataset, Version 3.0

title: Chinese Development Finance Commitments by Year and Flow Class — gcdf_yearly_flows
code: # Get total commitments by flow class gcdf_yearly_flows |>   dplyr::group_by(flow_class) |>   dplyr::summarize(     total_commitments_bn = sum(commitments_bn, na.rm = TRUE)   ) #> # A tibble: 3 × 2 #>   flow_class               total_commitments_bn #>   <chr>                                   <dbl> #> 1 ODA-like                                139.  #> 2 OOF-like                               1292.  #> 3 Vague (Official Finance)                 74.5  # Plot time series of commitments by flow class if (requireNamespace("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE)) {   ggplot2::ggplot(     gcdf_yearly_flows,     ggplot2::aes(x = commitment_year, y = commitments_bn, color = flow_class)   ) +     ggplot2::geom_line() }

what: Create AidData color scales for ggplot2 — scale_color_aiddata
title: Create AidData color scales for ggplot2 — scale_color_aiddata
text: Functions create color fill scales using AidData's color palettes. functions implement William & Mary's brand guidelines way works well data visualization.

title: Create AidData color scales for ggplot2 — scale_color_aiddata
code: scale_color_aiddata(palette = "default", reverse = FALSE, discrete = TRUE, ...)  scale_fill_aiddata(palette = "default", reverse = FALSE, discrete = TRUE, ...)

title: Create AidData color scales for ggplot2 — scale_color_aiddata
text: palette name palette use: "default", "one_color" "five_colors": Categorical palettes 1-5 colors "sequential_green", "sequential_gold": ordered data "diverging_green_gold", "diverging_vine_sky": data meaningful center point reverse Boolean indicating whether reverse palette order discrete Boolean indicating whether scale discrete (TRUE) continuous (FALSE) ... Additional arguments passed discrete_scale() scale_color_gradientn()

title: Create AidData color scales for ggplot2 — scale_color_aiddata
text: ggplot2 color fill scale

title: Create AidData color scales for ggplot2 — scale_color_aiddata
code: library(ggplot2)  # Basic usage with default palette (3 colors) ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg, color = factor(cyl))) +   geom_point() +   scale_color_aiddata()   # Using specific number of colors ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg, color = factor(gear))) +   geom_point() +   scale_color_aiddata(palette = "two_colors")   # Sequential palette for continuous data ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg, color = disp)) +   geom_point() +   scale_color_aiddata(palette = "sequential_green", discrete = FALSE)   # Fill scale with diverging palette ggplot(mtcars, aes(factor(cyl), fill = factor(gear))) +   geom_bar() +   scale_fill_aiddata(palette = "diverging_green_gold")

title: AidData ggplot2 theme — theme_aiddata
text: ggplot2 theme implements William & Mary brand guidelines optimized AidData's common visualization types. Works best Roboto Open Sans fonts installed, fall back system fonts necessary.

title: AidData ggplot2 theme — theme_aiddata
code: theme_aiddata(   base_font = "Open Sans",   title_font = "Roboto",   base_size = 11,   grid = TRUE,   map = FALSE )

title: AidData ggplot2 theme — theme_aiddata
text: base_font Base font family (default: "Open Sans") title_font Title font family (default: "Roboto") base_size Base font size (default: 11) grid Show major grid lines (default: TRUE) map Optimize map visualizations (default: FALSE)

title: AidData ggplot2 theme — theme_aiddata
text: ggplot2 theme

title: AidData ggplot2 theme — theme_aiddata
code: # \donttest{ library(ggplot2) # Set up ragg device ragg::agg_png(tempfile(), width = 600, height = 400, units = "px")  # Basic usage, falling back to system fonts if needed p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg)) +   geom_point() +   labs(title = "MPG vs Weight") +   theme_aiddata() #> Warning: Recommended fonts not found. Using fallback fonts: #>   Base font: sans #>   Title font: sans #> Use install_aiddata_fonts() to install recommended fonts. print(p) invisible(dev.off()) # }

title: AidData complete theme — theme_aiddata_complete
text: complete theme applies AidData's visual style color scales. function combines theme_aiddata() appropriate color scales.

title: AidData complete theme — theme_aiddata_complete
code: theme_aiddata_complete(   base_font = "Open Sans",   title_font = "Roboto",   base_size = 11,   grid = TRUE,   palette = "default",   discrete_fill = TRUE )

title: AidData complete theme — theme_aiddata_complete
text: base_font Base font family (default: "Open Sans") title_font Title font family (default: "Roboto") base_size Base font size (default: 11) grid Show major grid lines (default: TRUE) palette Color palette use (default: "default") discrete_fill Use discrete fill scale (default: TRUE)
